(3) Three kinds of future scenarios simulation results indicate that the average SEM will decrease by 2.40 t/(km2·a) under the natural development scenario and by 1.86 t/(km2·a) under the ecological protection scenario by 2060. However, under the cropland protection scenario, there is a slight increase in SEM, with an increase of 0.08 t/(km2·a). Sloping cropland erosion control remains a primary issue for Hainan Island in the future.

title: Land use land cover change in the African Great Lakes Region: a spatial–temporal analysis and future predictions
abstract: Abstract The African Great Lakes Region has experienced substantial land use land cover change (LULCC) over the last decades, driven by a complex interplay of various factors. However, a comprehensive analysis exploring the relationships between LULCC, and its explanatory variables remains unexplored. This study focused on the Lake Kivu catchment in Rwanda, analysing LULCC from 1990 to 2020, identifying major variables, and predicting future LULC scenarios under different development trajectories. Image classification was conducted in Google Earth Engine using random forest classifier, by incorporating seasonal composites Landsat images, spectral indices, and topographic features, to enhance discrimination and capture seasonal variations. The results demonstrated an overall accuracy exceeding 83%. Historical analysis revealed significant changes, including forest loss (26.6 to 18.7%) and agricultural land expansion (27.7 to 43%) in the 1990–2000 decade, attributed to political conflicts and population movements. Forest recovery (24.8% by 2020) was observed in subsequent decades, driven by Rwanda’s sustainable development initiatives. A Multi-Layer Perceptron neural network from Land Change Modeler predicted distinct 2030 and 2050 LULC scenarios based on natural, socio-economic variables, and historical transitions. Analysis of explanatory variables highlighted the significant role of proximity to urban centers, population density, and terrain in LULCC. Predictions indicate distinct trajectories influenced by demographic and socio-economic trends. The study recommends adopting the Green Growth Economy scenario aligned with ongoing conservation measures. The findings contribute to identifying opportunities for land restoration and conservation efforts, promoting the preservation of Lake Kivu catchment’s ecological integrity, in alignment with national and global goals. Graphical Abstract

title: Global Land Use Change and Its Impact on Greenhouse Gas Emissions
abstract: ABSTRACT Anthropogenic activities have altered approximately two‐thirds of the Earth's land surface. Urbanization, industrialization, agricultural expansion, and deforestation are increasingly impacting the terrestrial landscapes, leading to shifts of areas in artificial surface (i.e., humanmade), cropland, pasture, forest, and barren land. Land use patterns and associated greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions play a critical role in global climate change. Here we synthesized 29 years of global historical data and demonstrated how land use impacts global GHG emissions using structural equation modeling. We then obtained predictive estimates of future global GHG emissions using a deep learning model. Our results show that, from 1992 to 2020, the global terrestrial areas covered by artificial surface and cropland have expanded by 133% and 6% because of population growth and socioeconomic development, resulting in 4.0% and 3.8% of declines in pasture and forest areas, respectively. Land use was significantly associated with GHG emissions ( p < 0.05). Artificial surface dominates global GHG emissions, followed by cropland, pasture, and barren land. The increase in artificial surfaces has driven up global GHG emissions through the increase in energy consumption. Conversely, improved agricultural management practices have contributed to mitigating agricultural GHG emissions. Forest, on the other hand, serves as a sink of GHG. In total, global GHG emissions increased from 31 to 46 GtCO 2 eq from 1992 to 2020. Looking ahead, if current trends in global land use continue at the same rates, our model projects that global GHG emissions will reach 76 ± 8 GtCO 2 eq in 2050. In contrast, reducing the rates of land use change by half could limit global GHG emissions to 60 ± 3 GtCO 2 eq in 2050. Monitoring and analyzing these projections allow a better understanding of the potential impacts of various land use scenarios on global climate and planning for a sustainable future.

title: Gene Identification and Map Construction of the Production &minus; Living &minus; Ecological Space in Traditional Villages in the Li River Basin
abstract: <sec><title>Objective</title> Traditional villages in the Li River Basin are key cultural heritage assets, representing the historical evolution of local societies, architectural traditions, and the complex interactions between human activities and natural landscapes. These villages, which exhibit distinct spatial patterns and cultural expressions, are central to understanding rural cultural landscapes in China. However, rapid urbanization has intensified pressures on these villages, resulting in challenges such as spatial homogenization, functional decline, and disordered development, all of which contribute to the erosion of the unique spatial characteristics of such villages. To address these critical issues, this research aims to identify and analyze the spatial genes of traditional villages in the Li River Basin. By constructing a comprehensive framework that integrates production, living, and ecological spaces, the research seeks to provide a theoretical foundation for the conservation, adaptive reuse, and sustainable management of these traditional landscapes within the broader framework of national and regional territorial spatial planning. </sec><sec><title>Methods</title> The research employs an innovative mixed-methods approach that combines deep learning techniques, spatial feature quantification, and extensive field investigations. A comprehensive spatial information database is developed, drawing information from multiple sources such as remote sensing imagery, historical documents, architectural surveys, and field observations. This database serves as the foundation for spatial analysis, facilitating the identification of spatial genes using a deep learning model, the Dual Attention Network (DANet). The model is designed to enhance spatial feature extraction through a combination of spatial and channel attention mechanisms, with a view to enabling more precise identification of spatial characteristics. The research categorizes spatial genes into three main types: Production space, living space, and ecological space. Production space mainly involves the forms of farmland and the relationship between village and farmland, reflecting the close integration of village with agricultural land. Living space encompasses settlement scale, settlement morphology, and road network patterns. Ecological space includes terrain type, landform type, village – mountain relationship, and village – water relationship, emphasizing the spatial relationship between village location and natural elements like mountains and water. The research also constructs a detailed spatial gene map that visually represents the organization and integration of production, living, and ecological spaces within traditional villages, providing insights into the dynamic interactions among these elements. </sec><sec><title>Results</title> The research identifies 32 distinct spatial gene types across traditional villages in the Li River Basin, which are systematically categorized into four main village types based on their spatial gene combinations and adaptation strategies. The first type, Surrounding Solitary Peak Village, is typically located in low-elevation karst landscapes, characterized by a circular spatial layout around isolated peaks and close proximity to water sources. These villages exhibit a strategic use of natural terrain, enabling effective agricultural production and compact living environments that are adapted to local topography. The second type, Peak Forest Depression Village, is found in hilly and plain karst areas. These villages feature compact living spaces but more dispersed production areas, reflecting adaptations to limited ecological space and a strong reliance on local natural resources. The third type, River Valley Plain Village, is situated along river valleys and plains, with residential and production spaces closely aligned with water channels. These villages often serve as commercial centers with well-developed waterway networks, demonstrating a functional balance between agricultural production and trade activities. The fourth type, Mountainous Hill Village, is located at higher elevations and characterized by stepped terraces, tiered housing, and adaptive land use patterns that integrate with the steep terrain. These villages employ innovative land management strategies, such as contour farming and hillside construction, to maximize the use of available land while maintaining ecological balance. The spatial gene map constructed in this research offers a comprehensive visualization of the spatial organization and integration patterns within these villages, highlighting how different types of traditional villages maintain a balance among production, living, and ecological spaces. The map also reveals varying adaptation strategies shaped by local geographic, cultural, and economic factors, providing valuable insights into the sustainability of traditional village landscapes. </sec><sec><title>Conclusion</title> This research makes significant contributions to traditional village research by introducing an innovative framework for spatial gene identification and analysis, specifically focusing on the Li River Basin. Through the systematic classification of spatial genes into production, living, and ecological spaces, the research not only refines the theoretical understanding of traditional village landscapes, but also provides practical guidance for their conservation and revitalization. The use of the DANet deep learning model enhances the objectivity, precision, and efficiency of spatial gene identification and mapping, thereby establishing a comprehensive spatial gene database. The spatial gene map constructed in this research effectively visualizes the interactions and combination patterns of spatial elements, offering clear insights into the strategies for classification and sustainable development of villages. The findings underscore the need to harmonize traditional spatial characteristics with modern development requirements, advocating for a balanced integration of historical heritage within the context of contemporary societal demands. By supporting policy formulation aligned with territorial spatial governance and regional planning, this research contributes to the sustainable development of traditional villages, as well as the preservation of cultural identity and the accommodation of modern needs. </sec>

title: Ecology of Lake Erie - Nutrients, microbes, algae, and dreissenid mussels: A synthesis
abstract: The Lake Erie ecosystem, including its physical, chemical, and biological components, has changed considerably during recent decades owing to human-induced environmental stress (Fraker et al., 2022; Makarewicz and Bertram, 1991; Munawar and Munawar, 1976; Sinclair et al., 2021). While much has been learned from monitoring and research activities, a full understanding of how and why the ecosystem has changed is lacking (Fraker et al., 2023; Fussell et al., 2016; Sterner et al., 2017; Scavia et al., 2023), which has hampered the development of management strategies that can help sustain the integrity of the lake and its valued ecosystem services (e.g. clean water, safe recreation, food production). This AEHM special issue is the first of four focused on Lake Erie, all of which will aim to display the science being conducted to enhance ecosystem understanding and guide management decision-making.This special issue centers on watershed, nutrient, microbial (including cyanobacteria), algal, and dreissenid mussel dynamics, including their causes and consequences. Specifically, it focuses on understanding factors that have driven changes in: 1) nutrient loading and in-lake nutrient dynamics; 2) algal and cyanobacteria dynamics; and 3) dreissenid growth, impacts, and spatial variation. After recapping each paper's major messages and management implications, we offer some concluding remarks.Since the early 2000s, Lake Erie has shown signs of intensified eutrophication, including increases in the extent and duration of hypoxia and harmful algal blooms dominated by cyanobacteria (hereafter, cyanoHABs; Scavia et al., 2014; Watson et al., 2016). Some of those symptoms have been linked to altered nutrient dynamics in Lake Erie's watersheds and, particularly, significant increases in dissolved reactive phosphorus loads (Baker et al., 2014; Stumpf et al., 2016). The source of most phosphorus entering Lake Erie is agriculture (Wilson et al., 2018); however, this source is dispersed across the landscape (Kast et al., 2021) and difficult to mitigate. Thus, delineating the characteristics of watersheds that export the largest amount of nutrients is important to identifying locations where nutrient reduction will be most effective. While reducing nutrient input is critical, the behavior of nutrients once they have entered the lake is likely to influence where and when cyanoHABs occur. Toward improving our understanding of eutrophication, two of this AEHM special issue's contributors focused on identifying causes of variation in the dynamics of nutrient loading and approaches to model the availability of these loads on chemicophysical conditions.Johnson et al. (2023) sought to identify how watershed characteristics have influenced nutrient and sediment inputs into western Lake Erie. To this end, these authors used a suite of physical attributes, land uses, and point-source contributions to characterize seven tributary watersheds, six of which are Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement Annex 4 priority watersheds, and five sub-watersheds. The authors then used principal components regression analysis to determine their relationship with nutrient and sediment yields into Lake Erie. Briefly, their results demonstrated spatial (regional) variation in contributions of nutrients and sediments from each river during 2017-2021 that was related to watershed attributes. For example, nutrient inputs into Lake Erie from watersheds were positively related to the percentage of land supporting cultivated crops and poorly drained soils, with higher slopes and lower amounts of pasture being positively correlated with sediment yields. These authors then discussed their findings in the context of impending nutrient reductions aimed at mitigation of Lake Erie's recent re-eutrophication (Baker et al., 2019), explaining how consideration of regional differences in nutrient and sediment yields could benefit nutrient management planning.While Johnson et al. centered on factors that influence nutrient and sediment loading into Lake Erie, Bocaniov et al. (2023) focused how nutrient (total phosphorus, TP) inputs affect within-lake TP movement and distribution. These authors used an updated phosphorus mass-balance model (2003-2016) to derive TP load-response relationships and response matrices to predict steady-state lake TP concentrations as a function of variable external TP inputs. A key finding is that inter-basin transfer of TP plays a large role in driving basin-specific TP concentrations (e.g. inflow from the central basin contributes ∼70% of the resident TP in the eastern basin). Bocaniov et al.'s modeling also demonstrated that western Lake Erie is likely to respond quickly (93 days) to reduced TP inputs, with longer response times estimated in the central and eastern basins (540 and 303 days, respectively). These authors then discuss how their findings can help guide where in the watershed to manage nutrients and what timeframes may be needed before agencies can expect to see impacts of nutrient abatement efforts.An outcome of excessive agricultural nutrient loading into aquatic ecosystems is enhanced primary production. Lake Erie has experienced increases in benthic algae (e.g. Cladophora), pelagic algae, and cyanobacteria during both past (1960s-1970s) and more recent eutrophication events (Munawar and Munawar, 1996; O'Donnell et al., 2023; Vollenweider et al., 1974; Watson et al., 2016). Lake Erie is a large and complex ecosystem, however, and the specific type or location of algal blooms cannot be predicted by nutrient loading alone. Rather, how and where blooms form will depend on complex processes such as gazing pressure and nutrient availability within the lake, as well as water warming that will interact with high nutrient availability. With this backdrop, four papers in this AEHM special issue sought to enhance our ability to understand and describe the dynamics of primary producers, including algae and cyanobacteria.To help better understand the mechanisms responsible for benthic Cladophora outbreaks in eastern Lake Erie since dreissenid mussels colonized the lake, Depew et al. (2023) quantified the enzymatically hydrolysable portion (EHP) of dissolved organic phosphorus (DOP). Samples were collected during May through September 2019 at varying depths along the north shore of the eastern basin. These authors found that the EHP substantially contributed to the dissolved P pool, with this contribution averaging 53% of the total dissolved P and 63% of the DOP concentration. Hence, a large amount of DOP appears bioavailable owing to enzymatic hydrolysis. This result, combined with the fact that bioavailable DOP concentrations often exceeded dissolved reactive P concentrations, indicates an increased role of the benthic contributions to P bioavailability in the eastern basin since the establishment of dreissenid mussels. In turn, Depew et al. highlight the need to consider EHP when designing management strategies to control Cladophora outbreaks in the eastern basin.In contrast to Depew et al., Hoffman et al. (2023) quantified seasonal nitrification in Lake Erie's water column and explored its potential role in driving microbial dynamics, including cyanoHABs dominated by Microcystis spp. To do so, these authors used the stable isotope, 15NH4+, to track nitrification and qPCR to determine the relative abundances of ammonia oxidizing organisms (i.e. bacteria and Archaea, AOO) during 2015-2017. Hoffman et al. found that nitrification rates were lower during cyanoHABs, suggesting that AOOs were not good competitors with cyanobacteria for ammonia. These low rates can in part explain why cyanoHABs dominated by Microcystis spp. (non-nitrogen fixers) can persist despite low bioavailable nitrogen (N). Further, the removal of bioavailable N via coupled nitrification-denitrification is lower than the increase in bioavailable N through regeneration and external N loading. Using these findings, Hoffman et al. discuss the importance of reducing N loading into Lake Erie as a means to help reduce seasonal cyanoHABs.Hounshell et al. (2023) also focused on understanding cyanoHAB dynamics, exploring the role of P as a driver instead of N. While total bioavailable P (TBP) loading from the Maumee River (Ohio, USA) during spring has been shown to be a strong predictor of cyanoHAB severity in western Lake Erie (Baker et al., 2014; Bertani et al., 2016; Stumpf et al., 2016), much unexplained variation in cyanoHAB severity remains. Thus, Hounshell et al. (2023) sought to identify environmental variables that could improve the predictive relationship between the Maumee River spring TBP load and cyanoHAB severity. Their modeling showed that at both low (< 273 MTA) and high (> 332 MTA) TBP loads levels, no other environmental factors improved predictive accuracy of cyanoHABs in western Lake Erie. However, during years with intermediate springtime TBP loads (273-332 MTA), predictions of cyanoHABs could be improved by considering winter and July TBP loads, as well as ice extent and phenology. While their work is still ongoing, Hounshell et al.'s research highlights the value of both tributary and in-lake monitoring, as well as process-based modeling to cyanoHAB forecasting.Wang et al. (2023) also sought to use modeling to predict the distribution of cyanoHABs in Lake Erie. Specifically, these authors compared the performance of the one-dimensional (1D) Aquatic Ecosystem Dynamics–General Lake Model (AED–GLM) and the three-dimensional (3D) Aquatic Ecosystem Model (AEM3D–iWQ) in predicting cyanoHABs, phytoplankton biomass (as measured by chlorophyll a), and associated physicochemical conditions (e.g. water temperature, nutrients), among other things, in western Lake Erie during 2008 and 2011-2014. By qualitatively comparing their results to in situ observations, Wang et al. showed that the 3D model better reproduced seasonal and spatial variation in nutrients and phytoplankton with less error than the 1D model. Conversely, cyanoHABs were better predicted by the 1D model. As detailed in their paper, Wang et al. explain how the scale at which these models are calibrated can drive differences in model performance. These authors also discuss the implications of their findings for choosing the appropriate model to support management endeavors, including how to best calibrate them to achieve desired goals.The final set of papers centered on invasive dreissenid mussels, which have become a ubiquitous part of the Great Lakes since their introduction nearly four decades ago (Nalepa et al., 2005). Owing to their potential to negatively impact native mussels (Schloesser et al., 2006), zooplankton communities (Johannsson et al., 2000), phytoplankton biomass (Bocaniov et al., 2014), and nutrient cycling (Hecky et al., 2004), Zebra (Dreissena polymorpha) and Quagga (D. rostiformis bugensis) Mussels have garnered the interest of researchers and management agencies alike. Much of this effort has been devoted to understanding the mechanisms that influence dreissenid demographics and impacts of the food web, which are the focus of the last set of papers in this AEHM special issue.To understand the growth dynamics of dreissenid mussels and their impact on phytoplankton in western Lake Erie, Carter et al. (2023) combined field surveys, in situ growth experiments, and laboratory excretion and grazing experiments. Their results, which are important in interpreting two of the remaining AEHM special issue papers, showed that dreissenid communities have lower clearance rates and excretion rates compared to previously reported rates. This understanding, combined with reduced dreissenid densities in Lake Erie during recent decades, led Carter et al. to conclude that the ability of dreissenids to compound the effect of eutrophication that causes cyanoHABs may be less than previously thought (e.g. Vanderploeg et al., 2009; but see Carrick et al., 2023 and Vanderploeg et al., 2023). Carter et al. (2023) acknowledge, however, that the impact of dreissenids could be locally high at times, owing to their patchy distribution across the basin. In turn, these authors stress the need for frequent, fine-scale benthic surveys, which could improve ability to understand and forecast the impacts of dreissenids on the ecosystem.Carrick et al. (2023) also sought to quantify the impact of dreissenid mussels on plankton assemblages (heterotrophs and phototrophs) in western Lake Erie. Using controlled experiments conducted monthly during May through October 2018, these authors show that dreissenids graze actively throughout the growing season, consuming nano-sized heterotrophic and phototrophic plankton (e.g. phototrophic cryptophytes, centric diatoms, and non-pigmented chrysomonads). By contrast, lower clearance rates of cyanobacteria (e.g. Microcystis spp.), dinoflagellates, and some colonial chlorophytes were observed. Carrick et al. further suggest that selective dreissenid grazing on "non-harmful" plankton species in the nanoplankton size range, combined with lower grazing rates on larger cyanobacteria and chlorophyte species, could contribute to western Lake Erie's cyanoHAB problem. Notably, the small-scale experimental results of Carrick et al. contrast those from Carter et al.'s (2023) field-based study. This discrepancy highlights the value of both experimental and field-based approaches, as well as the need to carefully consider the spatiotemporal context of the investigation, when to quantifying the role of dreissenid grazing as a secondary promoter (above nutrient loading) of cyanoHABs.Vanderploeg et al. (2023) also used an experimental approach to quantity the impacts of dreissenid mussel grazing on the phytoplankton community. Their experiments showed that grazing pressure on phytoplankton varied during May through October, with grazing on cryptophytes and diatoms being high during late May through early July. Despite cyanophytes dominating the phytoplankton beginning in late July, dreissenid grazing on them was non-existent or low. Interestingly, 16S rRNA gene-sequencing analyses showed a diverse cyanobacteria community with Planktothrix dominating during the spring and Cyanobium dominating most of the summer through fall. By contrast, Microcystis, which is largely thought to dominate cyanoHABs in Lake Erie, only dominated during late June. Further, Microcystis was preferentially rejected by Quagga Mussels relative to other cyanobacteria. Using these findings, Vanderploeg et al. draw a similar conclusion as Carrick et al. (2023) by suggesting that dreissenid grazing can favor specific cyanobacteria such as Microcystis. Importantly, however, the final effect of dreissenid grazing as a secondary promoter of cyanoHABS depends on the population density of dreissenids, which is currently low (Carter et al., 2023).In this special issue's final paper, Elgin et al. (2023) conducted an in situ study to quantify spatial variation in colonization potential, growth rates, and abundance of dreissenid mussels at two sites with contrasting water-column conditions in western Lake Erie. Despite finding comparable dreissenid colonization potential and growth between study sites, both on and in the experimental cages, Elgin et al. found fewer mussels in the surrounding sediment at the site nearer the Maumee River. These authors use this finding to conclude that water-column conditions appear to favor dreissenid settlement and growth on hard surfaces suspended above the substrate across the western basin, but that conditions on or near the substrate may inhibit mussel settling and growth. Elgin et al. eventually discuss how substrate-driven bottlenecks could inform our understanding of dreissenid recruitment and distribution, as well as nutrient dynamics, in western Lake Erie. These authors also suggest how better characterization of substrate conditions could support dreissenid control efforts.Owing to the impact of humans, the world's ecosystems have been experiencing dramatic change, which has threatened their structure, function, and dynamics, as well as their capacity to support services valued by society. The world's Great Lakes are no exception with these ecosystems being degraded by numerous anthropogenic stressors, including nutrient alteration (both eutrophication and oligotrophication), non-native species invasions, habitat destruction, and climate change, among many others (Allan et al., 2013; Jenny, 2020; Odada et al., 2003). The magnitude, multitude, and simultaneous nature of these stressors have in turn challenged both researchers seeking to understand the dynamics of these ecosystems and agencies charged with managing the valued natural resources (e.g. fish, wildlife) and other services (e.g. safe drinking water, recreational opportunities) that these ecosystems provide (Allan et al., 2013; Odada and Olago, 2006; Sterner et al., 2017). Such challenges highlight the need for continued research aimed at understanding the causes and consequences of anthropogenic change.While all the large lakes of the world have been altered by anthropogenic stress, Lake Erie is among the most degraded. Its susceptibility to anthropogenic stress is largely due to its small size, shallow depth, high connectivity via shipping, and large watershed that supports both large cities and agricultural production (Fraker et al, 2022; Ludsin et al., 2001; Reutter, 2019). Most relevant to this AEHM special issue, Lake Erie has shifted trophic states multiple times in response to human impacts and subsequent mitigation efforts. Prior to the 1950s, Lake Erie was primarily in a pre-industrial state of mesotrophy-oligotrophy and shifted to a state of hypertrophy-mesotrophy during the 1960s-1970s. During the 1980s-1990s, it shifted back to more mesotrophic conditions in response to both mitigation efforts designed to reduce point-source inputs of TP and the invasion of dreissenid mussels. Most recently (post 2000), Lake Erie returned to a more eutrophic state due to non-point source runoff of dissolved reactive phosphorus (Kane et al., 2014; Ludsin et al., 2001; Sinclair et al., 2023; Vollenweider et al., 1974). Concomitantly, Lake Erie has currently been experiencing increases in the magnitude and extent of both bottom hypoxia and cyanoHABs (Scavia et al., 2014; Watson et al., 2016), which are threatening: human health through cyanotoxin exposure (e.g. Francy et al., 2016; Wituszynski et al., 2017); fish populations and the fisheries that they support (e.g. Stone et al., 2020; Wolf et al., 2017); and the regional economy through effects on tourism and property values (Smith et al., 2019; Wolf et al., 2022). These threats have increased the need for the science necessary to make informed management decisions (Fraker et al., 2023; Fussell et al., 2016; Sterner et al., 2017; Scavia et al., 2023), which includes describing the current state of the Lake Erie ecosystem and understanding the causal mechanisms of recent ecosystem change.The contributions to this AEHM special issue have provided new insights into the drivers of nutrient inputs, in-lake nutrient concentrations, benthic algae (Cladophora), planktonic heterotrophs, microbial autotrophs (including cyanobacteria responsible for cyanoHABs), algae (e.g. diatoms, cryptophytes), and dreissenid mussels. Further, each study has provided information that could benefit management, whether it be ecological understanding that could support ecosystem modeling (e.g. quantifying dreissenid distributions and their impacts on grazing rates and nutrient excretion; Carter et al., 2023; Elgin et al., 2023) or tools that could support nutrient management decision-making (e.g. Bocaniov et al., 2023; Johnson et al, 2023), cyanoHAB severity (e.g. Carrick et al.,. 2023; Hounshell et al., 2023; Vanderploeg et al., 2023) or chemicophysical conditions, including algal and cyanobacteria biomass (e.g. Depew et al., 2023; Hoffman et al., 2023; Wang et al., 2023). While many additional messages can be found in the papers, collectively, three key conclusions can be made. First, findings from each of the three focal areas of this AEHM special issue highlight the need to consider fine spatial and/or temporal scales in both the watershed and the lake proper. Doing so offers a means to fully appreciate the complex array of processes driving the dynamics of Lake Erie's chemicophysical conditions and lower food web (e.g. primary producers, dreissenid mussels). Second, while the papers in this special issue showed the value of field-, laboratory-, and modeling-based research to describing, understanding, or predicting ecosystem conditions, they also pointed to challenges that can arise when integrating findings. For example, discrepancies can arise owing to studies being conducted in different settings (e.g. in the laboratory vs. in the field) or at different spatiotemporal scales (e.g. see Carrick et al., 2023; Carter et al., 2023; Vanderploeg et al., 2023). Finally, most papers demonstrated the need for continued and intensified monitoring (e.g. broader coverage at finer spatial and temporal scales), which will challenge agencies responsible for tracking ecosystem conditions. We expect, however, that continued improvement in our ability to cost-effectively monitor Lake Erie and its watershed via remote sensing technologies (Yang et al., 2022; Yin et al., 2021), combined with continually improving data-analytic approaches (e.g. machine and deep learning; Sun and Scanlon, 2019), will help agencies meet this challenge.While the research described in this AEHM special issue has addressed many knowledge gaps, many more remain. Our hope is that continued reporting of findings as part of this AEHM Ecology of Lake Erie series will increase our ability to understand and model the structure, function, and dynamics of the ecosystem. Such understanding and tools should facilitate our continued movement towards ecosystem-based management in the Great Lakes, which could help agencies rehabilitate the lake and sustainably manage its valued resources in the face of continued anthropogenic stress.We thank Ken Minns for providing helpful feedback on a previous version of this synthesis.

title: Earth Observations, Digital Footprints and Machine-Learning: Greenhouse Gas Stocktaking for Climate Change Mitigation
abstract: Introduction & BackgroundMethane (CH4) is a powerful greenhouse gas, leaving both a physical and digital footprint from natural (40%) and human (60%) sources. Its atmospheric concentration has increased from 722 ppb before the industrial age to ~1,922 ppb in recent times. Because of its global warming potential, measuring and monitoring CH4 is crucial to mitigating the impacts of climate change. However, large uncertainties exist in “bottom-up” inventories (a product of activity data based on counts of components, equipment or throughput, and estimates of gas-loss rates per unit of activity for different land uses) reported to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, making it difficult for policymakers to set emission reduction targets. To address this, we employ causality-constrained machine learning (ML) to combine different gas observations from satellite sensors onboard the TROPOspheric Monitoring Instrument (which measure a digital footprint of human methane-generating behaviour) with outputs from chemical modelling. These are linked with datasets from the national statistics office, meteorology office and a comprehensive survey on quality of life in the emission field, to improve bottom-up estimates of CH4 emissions at the Earth’s surface. Objectives & ApproachThe research uses mixed methods for collecting and analysing both qualitative and quantitative data for multidisciplinary processing strategies for monitoring CH4 emissions locally and regionally. It also assesses whether additional “digital footprint” variables besides the well-known chemical sources and sinks can be studied to improve our understanding of the CH4 budget. We have conducted an “analytical inversion” of satellite observations of CH4 to obtain emission fluxes. These represent the dependent variable for our ML model, in combination with 22 independent variables (co-occurring trace gases, meteorological fields, land use, land cover, population, livestock, and data from a survey of quality of life from the Gauteng City-Region Observatory, covering a broad range of socio-economic, personal and political issues) with near-real-time Earth observation data, to aid the development of a causality-constrained ML model for the prediction of CH4 fluxes. Relevance to Digital FootprintsWe make use of not only satellite imagery, but socio-economic, demographic, and environmental data, and repurpose it for environmental sustainability in the context of mitigating climate change. We are creating unique resources in documenting rapid changes in emissions. Conclusions & ImplicationsThis research will make important contributions to developing countries with limited resources, enabling them to contribute to the global stocktake towards net-zero by helping policymakers identify geographic regions that are major emitters, enabling them to put measures into place to mitigate emissions.
